newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico stocks end flat after rebound from profit-taking.
newsitem.headline: Mexico stocks end flat after rebound from profit-taking.

text.p: Mexican stocks recouped earlier losses to close almost flat on Friday, but well above the landmark 5,000-point barrier, as bargain-hunters were inspired by a similar recovery on Wall Street and shifted funds to Mexico from Brazil.
The leading IPC share index ended down 0.8 point, or 0.02 percent, at 5,067.03.
A surge in the benchmark U.S. 30-year Treasury bond spurred investors to take profits from record gains chalked up on Thursday and pushed the IPC down as low as 4,981.85 in early trade.
"Two elements were at work today, profit-taking or consolidation, and the long bond, but mainly the latter," said Feliz Boni, research head at ING-Barings in Mexico.
"The fall was cushioned because long bond yields are still relatively low, and there were signs of funds transferring to Mexico from Brazil," he added.

The Bovespa index of most active stocks traded in Sao Paulo dived 4.76 percent to close at 12,259. Brokerage Salomon Brothers meanwhile cut its recommended portfolio weighting for Brazil, while raising Mexico.
Dealers said market heavyweights Telefonos de Mexico (Telmex) and Grupo Carso were pace-setters for the bourse, both ending unchanged after recovering from profit-taking.
Telecommunications firm Telmex ended at 21.60 pesos ($2.76) while conglomerate Carso closed at 62.40 pesos ($7.96).
Dealers pointed to a strong performance by construction companies and some cement stocks.
The stocks gained on speculation that a government scheme to restructure highway concession debts was imminent.
Construction firm Empresas ICA gained 70 centavos (9 cents) to 24.70 pesos ($3.15), while cement maker Cemex climbed 1.00 (13 cents) peso to 40.20 pesos ($5.13).
Trading volume was brisk at 159.1 million shares, even after allowing for one cross trade which accounted for 47 million shares.
On the broad market, sliders outpaced gainers by 45 to 50, out of a total of 120 stocks traded.
